DOC.HEAD: Israeli Aide to Noriega Led Bungled Spy Mission
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The former Israeli spy who was arrested in Panama as a top aide to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega headed one of the most bungled operations in the history of Israel's Mossad intelligence agency. Michael Harari, whose arrest by U.S. troops was announced Thursday, was described by an American diplomat in Panama as a security adviser to Noriega and an instructor to the Panamanian Defense Forces. Israeli newspapers reported that Harari had considerable influence in Panamanian politics. He was once appointed by Noriega as Panama's honorary consul general in Israel. But he is best known, according to the daily Yediot Ahronot, as the head of a team of 15 Mossad agents who set out to kill a leading Palestinian terrorist but instead murdered a hapless Moroccan-born waiter in a Norwegian resort. Spokesmen for the Israeli Foreign and Defense ministries refused comment Friday on Harari's arrest in Panama, saying he was a private citizen. But his exploits have been described extensively in newspapers and books. Yediot said Harari helped Noriega recruit Israeli mercenaries for his personal bodyguard over the last year and noted that a second Israeli, Eliezer Ben Giton, surrendered to U.S. troops outside the Vatican mission in Panama, saying he was ``responsible for the personal security of General Manuel Noriega.'' The Haaretz daily said Harari was convinced to leave Panama last year by Israel officials, who were under strong U.S. pressure to cut contacts with Noriega. But the former Mossad agent later returned. Israel's ambassador to Panama, Reuven Ben-Eliezer, told Israel army radio he did not know Harari. ``I don't know who Harari is, I didn't see him, I didn't meet him, I didn't get orders from him, and he also didn't receive'' orders from Israel's embassy in Panama, Ben-Eliezer said in the interview broadcast Friday. ``He is a private Israeli. I don't know what he did there. He did business and he was appointed by Noriega as honorary general consul for Panama in Israel,'' Ben-Eliezer said. Harari, 62, was born in Tel Aviv in a religious family that objected to his joining the Israeli army. He eventually became a colonel. Yediot said Harari was chief of Mossad's special operations when he headed the unit trying to kill the leader of the Palestinian Black September group, which massacred 11 Israeli athletes at the 1972 Munich Olympics. The case is described in the book ``The Quest for the Red Prince'' by Israeli authors Michael Bar-Zohar and Eitan Haber. Haber, now the spokesman for Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin, refused to comment on the case. In the book, the team leader is referred to only as ``Mike,'' but sources familiar with the case say it was Harari. According to the accounts, Harari's squad traced the man they believed to be Ali Hassan Salameh, known as the Red Prince, to the resort of Lillehammer, Norway. Two agents killed the man on May 23, 1973, but the victim turned out to be Ahmed Boushiki, a Moroccan-born waiter living in Lillehammer with his Norwegian wife. The embarrassment was heightened when six of the Israeli agents involved in the mission were arrested by Norwegian police. The real Salameh was eventually killed when a bomb planted by Israeli agents engulfed his car in flames on a Beirut street on Jan. 22, 1979.
